Block description — Sections 1 to 2.2

▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄ 3. DETAILED BLOCK DESCRIPTION
This module, FC19512_StdDebugInst2Order uses user data types to provide the primary interface to the block. There are four formal parameters:
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― PARAM FUNCTION TYPE IN-OUT ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SYS_SIGNALS Common system signals UT21000 In logic and timing signals for parametric access
TRIGGER Activates the simulation (the simulation will run Bool In whilever this signal is high), the elapsed time is measured from the rising edge of this signal
INPUT The input time function, x(t) in the calculations Real In
DYNAMIC_DATA Data structure that holds the live data for the UT39512 InOut simulation (damping factor, natural frequency, system gain, elapsed time &c.)
OUTPUT The output time response, y(t) in the calculations Real Out ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
The DYNAMIC_DATA parameter is a UDT that holds all the data for the simulation.
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― PARAM ASSOCIATED UDT ASSOCIATED DATA BLOCK ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― DYNAMIC_DATA UT39512_Dy_DebugInst2Order DB39512_Dy_DebugInst2Order ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
Section 6 contains a full list of all variables within these UDTs.
▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 3.1 The primary simulation signals
The simulation is based upon various signals passed to the module and the elapsed time since the simulation started:
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SIGNAL FUNCTION RANGE ACCESSED VIA ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― INPUT The INPUT parameter is the x value Unrestricted Parameter in the calculations of § 2.3
OUTPUT The OUTPUT parameter is the y value Unrestricted Parameter in the calculations of § 2.3
TRIGGER The TRIGGER parameter activates 0 or 1 Parameter the simulation
k_Gain The system gain (K) term Unrestricted UT39512 in the calculations of § 2.3 typ. 1-10
k_NatFreq The natural frequency of the system +ve number UT39512 (ω) term in the calculations of § 2.3. typ. 1-100 In units of radians/second (rad/s)
k_DampFactor The damping factor of the system Unrestricted UT39512 (ζ) in the calculations of § 2.3
The damping factor determines the type of response: ζ > 1 Stable over damped (no oscillations) ζ = 1 Stable critically damped (no oscillations) 0 < ζ < 1 Stable under damped (decaying oscillations) ζ = 0 Stable undamped (constant oscillations) -1 < ζ < 0 Unstable under damped (inc. oscillations) ζ ≤ -1 Unstable over damped (asymptotic increase)
cal_DampFreqRS Damped (actual) frequency of +ve number UT39512 the system (rad/s). calculated by Ω in the calculations of § 2.3 the module
actual_StartTime The CPU time when the simulation DTL value UT39512 started (rising edge of TRIGGER) of RTC
actual_RunTime The elapsed time (t) term +ve number UT39512 in the calculations of § 2.3. calculated by Always measured in seconds the module Current CPU time - actual_StartTime ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
The most important of these terms is the damping factor (k_DampFactor), this determines the type of response (stable, unstable, oscillating, exponential &c.) and also the speed of the response, the smaller the damping factor, the faster the system will reach the steady state value (in the case where k_DampFactor is between zero and one, the steady state value will be reached quickly, but there will be some degree of overshoot, see the figures of § 2.3).
The natural frequency (k_NatFreq), determines the frequency of oscillation for those responses that oscillate (oscillations occur when –1 < k_DampFactor < +1). For non-oscillating responses, the larger the natural frequency, the quicker the response.
The system gain (k_Gain), is simply a common multiplier that amplifies the output response. By default the system gain is set to a value of one (i.e. unity gain). If the system gain k_Gain is set zero, the OUTPUT will be zero under all circumstances
The elapsed time actual_RunTime is calculated from the real time clock within the CPU. On the rising edge of the TRIGGER parameter, the CPU real time clock is read and the value stored in the variable actual_StartTime, on each subsequent call to the block, the real time clock is once again read and the actual_StartTime value is subtracted from this value to give the current elapsed time, this is converted to seconds and is stored as the actual_RunTime value.
The TRIGGER signal is simply used to start and stop the simulation. A rising edge on the TRIGGER signal causes the current CPU time to be stored (actual_StartTime) and sets the elapsed time to zero (actual_RunTime). The simulation will run whilever the TRIGGER signal is high (has a value of 1), each time the module is called, the elapsed time (actual_RunTime) is updated (see the previous paragraph) and the output calculated accordingly.
If the TRIGGER signal is low (0), the simulation is instantly stopped and the OUTPUT parameter is set to zero.
▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 3.2 The response calculation
The calculation that is performed by the module is entirely dependent on the k_DampFactor (referred to as ζ, the Greek letter Zeta, in the following equations).
The calculations given in section 2.3 (and summarised below) use Greek characters for the main variables, the calculations use various parameters and UDT variables that have plain English names, The association between these variables and the Greek nomenclature is given below.
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― ζ > 1 STABLE over damped (no oscillations) Equation (2.1)
╓ 1 ┌ ζ ┐ - ω [ ζ ─ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t 1 ┌ ζ ┐ - ω [ ζ ┼ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t ╖ y = x K║1 ─ -- │------------------ ┼ 1│ｅ ┼ -- │------------------ ─ 1│ｅ ║ ╙ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘ ╜ ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― ζ = 1 STABLE critically damped (no oscillations) Equation (2.2)
╓ - ωt ╖ y = x K║1 ─ (1 ┼ ωt) ｅ ║ ╙ ╜ ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― 0 < ζ < 1 STABLE under damped (decaying oscillations) Equation (2.3)
╓ - ζω t ┌ ζ ┐╖ y = x K║1 ─ ｅ │COS (Ωt) ┼ ------------------ SIN (Ωt)│║ where Ω = ω √(1 ─ ζ²) ╙ └ √(1 ─ ζ²) ┘╜ ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― ζ = 0 STABLE undamped (constant oscillations) Equation (2.4)
╓ ╖ y = x K║1 ─ COS (ωt) ║ ╙ ╜ ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― -1 < ζ < 0 UNSTABLE under damped (inc. oscillations) Equation (2.5)
╓ - ζω t ┌ ζ ┐╖ y = x K║1 ─ ｅ │COS (Ωt) ┼ ------------------ SIN (Ωt)│║ where Ω = ω √(1 ─ ζ²) ╙ └ √(1 ─ ζ²) ┘╜ ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― ζ ≤ -1 UNSTABLE over damped (asymptotic increase) Equation (2.6)
╓ 1 ┌ ζ ┐ - ω [ ζ ─ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t 1 ┌ ζ ┐ - ω [ ζ ┼ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t ╖ y = x K║1 ─ -- │------------------ ┼ 1│ｅ ┼ -- │------------------ ─ 1│ｅ ║ ╙ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘ ╜ ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
Where: x is the input signal, parameter INPUT y is the output response, parameter OUTPUT K is the system gain k_Gain ζ is the damping factor k_DampFactor ω is the natural frequency k_NatFreq Ω is the damped frequency cal_DampFreqRS t is the elapsed time actual_RunTime
The module will determine which calculation to perform based entirely on the value of the damping factor k_DampFactor (Greek symbol ζ) as shown above.
Each of these calculations, while being somewhat complicated and convoluted, can all be accommodated with the mathematical functions available to a Siemens Controller, see § 3.5.
▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 3.3 Status and informative signals
The module produces various status signals that reflect the nature of the simulation:
DATA STRUCTURE UT39512_Dy_DebugInst2Order ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SIGNAL FUNCTION TYPE DETAILS ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― status_Running The simulation is running Bool 1 = Simulation is running 0 = Simulation is stopped
status_Stopped The simulation is stopped Bool 1 = Simulation is stopped 0 = Simulation is running
status_Stable Simulation response type Bool 1 = Stable is stable 0 = Unstable
status_OverDamp Simulation response type: Bool 1 = Stable, over damped stable and over damped 0 = No value
status_CritDamp Simulation response type: Bool 1 = Stable, critically damped stable and critically damped 0 = No value
status_UnderDamp Simulation response type: Bool 1 = Stable, under damped stable and under damped 0 = No value
status_Undamped Simulation response type: Bool 1 = Stable, undamped stable and undamped 0 = No value
status_USUnder Simulation response type: Bool 1 = Unstable, under damped unstable and under damped 0 = No value
status_USOver Simulation response type: Bool 1 = Unstable, over damped unstable and over damped 0 = No value
status_SteadyState Simulation has achieved Bool 1 = Stady state achieved steady state ±2% 0 = Not in steady state ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
The status_Running and status_Stopped are determined purely by the status of the TRIGGER parameter, if this is set high (1), status_Running will be high and status_Stopped low. If TRIGGER parameter, if this is set low (0), status_Running will be low and status_Stopped high. The status_Running and status_Stopped signals are always the inverse of each other.
The six simulation response type signals are mutually exclusive, only one will be active if the simulation is running. Whichever is active, is determined by the k_DampFactor (ζ in the equations) as follows:
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SIGNAL FUNCTION OSCILLATING STABLE ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― status_OverDamp k_DampFactor > 1 NO YES status_CritDamp k_DampFactor = 1 NO YES status_UnderDamp 0 < k_DampFactor < 1 YES YES status_Undamped k_DampFactor = 0 YES YES status_USUnder –1 < k_DampFactor < 0 YES NO status_USOver k_DampFactor ≤ –1 NO NO ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
If the response is stable (k_DampFactor ≥ 0), status_Stable is set high (1), if the response is unstable (k_DampFactor < 0), status_Stable is set low (0).
If the response is stable (k_DampFactor ≥ 0), the status_SteadyState signal will be activated when the OUTPUT is within ±2% of the steady state value and remains within this tolerance (i.e. for the underdamped oscillatory response, the status_SteadyState signal will not activate until the oscillations have decayed to the point at which they remain within the ±2% of steady state value).
The module also produces some additional, informational, signals:
DATA STRUCTURE UT39512_Dy_DebugInst2Order ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SIGNAL FUNCTION TYPE DETAILS ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― status_Osc The response is oscillatory Bool 1 = Oscillating response 0 = non-oscillating response
status_OscFreqRS The actual frequency of Real Oscillating frequency (rad/s) oscillation in radians per second (ω or Ω in § 3.2)
status_OscFreqHz The actual frequency of Real Oscillating frequency (Hz) oscillation in Hertz (ω or Ω in the § 3.2)
status_Period The period of oscillation Real Period of oscillation (s) in seconds ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
If the response is oscillatory in nature (e.g. –1 < k_DampFactor < 1), the status_Osc signal will be set high (1), if the response is non-oscillatory in nature, status_Osc signal will be set low (0).
For oscillatory responses, the actual frequency of the oscillation is specified in radians per second in the signal status_OscFreqRS, and in Hertz in the status_OscFreqHz signal.
For undamped systems, the frequency is the equivalent to k_NatFreq (ω in the calculations above), for under damped systems this set to cal_DampFreqRS (Ω in the calculations above).
Note: cal_DampFreqRS is a calculated value, calculated internally by the module.
The actual period of oscillation, is given in status_Period and is always in units of seconds.
If the system is non-oscillatory, the signals status_OscFreqRS, status_OscFreqHz and status_Period are all set to zero.
▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 3.4 Understanding the responses
Section 2.3 gives graphical examples of the six types of 2nd order systems responses along with the calculation used to generate each type of response (summarised in § 3.2).
In all the examples of section 2.3, the system gain (k_Gain, K in the calculations) is set to 1, giving a common scale to the output responses. Setting a different value for k_Gain simply scales the results accordingly.
Various rules of thumb for each of the six types of responses are given in section 2.3, these are summarised below and where calculated by the module, the associated variable in the DYNAMIC_DATA parameter is specified.
The following is a full list of the variables associated with such calculated values:
Note: The following calculated value variables are not applicable to all response types, where a calculated value is not applicable to a particular response, it will be set to zero.
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SIGNAL FUNCTION RANGE ACCESSED VIA ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― cal_DampFreqRS Damped (actual) frequency of +ve number UT39512 the system (rad/s). calculated by Ω in the calculations below the module
cal_DampFreqHz Damped (actual) frequency of +ve number UT39512 the system (Hz). calculated by f in the calculations below the module
cal_Period Actual period of oscillation +ve number UT39512 in seconds (peak to peak). calculated by Tn in the calculations below the module
cal_Time60 Time to reach 60% of steady +ve number UT39512 state value (seconds) calculated by T60 in the calculations below the module
cal_TimeSteady Time to reach the steady +ve number UT39512 state value (seconds) calculated by TSS in the calculations below the module
cal_PeakValue Maximum overshoot as a percentage Unrestricted UT39512 of the steady state value Ypk in the calculations below
cal_TimePeak Time to reach the peak +ve number UT39512 output value (seconds) calculated by Tpk in the calculations below the module ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 3.4.1 Over damped, slow response no overshoot ζ > 1
CALCULATION:
╓ 1 ┌ ζ ┐ - ω [ ζ ─ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t 1 ┌ ζ ┐ - ω [ ζ ┼ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t ╖ y = x K║1 ─ -- │------------------ ┼ 1│ｅ ┼ -- │------------------ ─ 1│ｅ ║ ╙ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘ ╜ Note: • A lower damping factor ζ gives a faster response • A higher natural frequency ω gives a faster response
―― ANCILLARY CALCULATIONS WITH UDT SIGNALS: ―――――――――――――――――― DESCRIPTION CALCULATION SIGNAL (UT39512) ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― 1 Time to 60% of steady state value (s) T60 = ---------------------------------- cal_Time60 ω [ ζ ─ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]
4 Time to 98% of steady state value(s) TSS = ---------------------------------- cal_TimeSteady ω [ ζ ─ √(ζ² ─ 1) ] ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
The following variables are not used in this type of response and are set to zero: cal_DampFreqRS cal_DampFreqHz cal_Period cal_PeakValue cal_TimePeak
―― OTHER ANCILLARY CALCULATIONS WITHOUT UDT SIGNALS: ――――――――――――― ╓ - ω [ ζ ┼ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t ╖ Approx. first order response (ζ > 5) y(t) = K║x(t) ─ ｅ ║ ╙ ╜ ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 3.4.2 Critically damped, fastest response without overshoot ζ = 1
CALCULATION:
╓ ╖ y = x K║1 ─ COS (ωt) ║ ╙ ╜ Note: • A higher natural frequency ω gives a faster response
―― ANCILLARY CALCULATIONS WITH UDT SIGNALS: ―――――――――――――――――― DESCRIPTION CALCULATION SIGNAL (UT39512) ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― 2 Time to 60% of steady state value (s) T60 = ---- cal_Time60 ω
6 Time to 98% of steady state value (s) TSS = ---- cal_TimeSteady ω ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
The following variables are not used in this type of response and are set to zero: cal_DampFreqRS cal_DampFreqHz cal_Period cal_PeakValue cal_TimePeak
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 3.4.3 Under damped, decreasing oscillations 0 < ζ < 1
CALCULATION:
╓ - ζω t ┌ ζ ┐╖ y = x K║1 ─ ｅ │COS (Ωt) ┼ ------------------ SIN (Ωt)│║ where Ω = ω √(1 ─ ζ²) ╙ └ √(1 ─ ζ²) ┘╜ Note: • A lower damping factor ζ gives a faster response and higher frequency • A higher natural frequency ω gives a faster response and higher frequency
―― ANCILLARY CALCULATIONS WITH UDT SIGNALS: ―――――――――――――――――― DESCRIPTION CALCULATION SIGNAL (UT39512) ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― Damped frequency of oscillation (rad/s) Ω = ω √(1 ─ ζ²) cal_DampFreqRS
Ω Damped frequency of oscillation (Hz) f = ------ cal_DampFreqHz 2π

The following variables are not used in this type of response and are set to zero: cal_Time60

CALCULATION:
╓ ╖ y(t) = K║x(t) ─ COS (ωt) ║ ╙ ╜ Note: • A higher natural frequency ω gives a higher frequency
―― ANCILLARY CALCULATIONS WITH UDT SIGNALS: ―――――――――――――――――― DESCRIPTION CALCULATION SIGNAL (UT39512) ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― ω Frequency of oscillation (Hz) f = ------ status_OscFreqHz 2π
2π 1 Natural (actual) period of oscillation (s) Tn = ------ = ------ cal_Period ω f ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
The following variables are not used in this type of response and are set to zero: cal_DampFreqRS cal_DampFreqHz cal_Time60 cal_TimeSteady cal_PeakValue cal_TimePeak
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 3.4.5 Unstable, oscillations of increasing amplitude -1 < ζ < 0
CALCULATION:
╓ - ζω t ┌ ζ ┐╖ y = x K║1 ─ ｅ │COS (Ωt) ┼ ------------------ SIN (Ωt)│║ where Ω = ω √(1 ─ ζ²) ╙ └ √(1 ─ ζ²) ┘╜ Note: • A lower (increasingly negative) damping factor ζ gives a faster response and higher frequency • A higher natural frequency ω gives a higher frequency
Note: The magnitude of oscillation increases exponentially and is constrained only by the limits of the Controller, this will result in a cap of the OUTPUT value at ±3.4 × 10±38.
―― ANCILLARY CALCULATIONS WITH UDT SIGNALS: ―――――――――――――――――― DESCRIPTION CALCULATION SIGNAL (UT39512) ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― Damped frequency of oscillation (rad/s) Ω = ω √(1 ─ ζ²) cal_DampFreqRS
Ω Damped frequency of oscillation (Hz) f = ------ cal_DampFreqHz 2π
2π 1 Damped (actual) period of oscillation (s) Td = ------ = ------ cal_Period Ω f
――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
The following variables are not used in this type of response and are set to zero: cal_Time60 cal_TimeSteady cal_PeakValue cal_TimePeak
―― OTHER ANCILLARY CALCULATIONS WITHOUT UDT SIGNALS: ――――――――――――― - ζ ωt Oscillation acceleration curve = ｅ ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 3.4.6 Unstable, unbounded asymptotic increase ζ ≤ -1
CALCULATION:
╓ 1 ┌ ζ ┐ - ω [ ζ ─ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t 1 ┌ ζ ┐ - ω [ ζ ┼ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t ╖ y = x K║1 ─ -- │------------------ ┼ 1│ｅ ┼ -- │------------------ ─ 1│ｅ ║ ╙ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘ ╜
Note: • A lower (increasingly negative) damping factor ζ gives a faster response • A higher natural frequency ω gives a faster response
Note: The magnitude of oscillation increases exponentially and is constrained only by the limits of the Controller, this will result in a cap of the OUTPUT value at ±3.4 × 10±38.
The following variables are not used in this type of response and are set to zero: cal_DampFreqRS cal_DampFreqHz cal_Period cal_Time60 cal_TimeSteady cal_PeakValue cal_TimePeak
Block description — Section 3 to 3.2

▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 3.5 Expressing the calculations in Controller operations
The calculations above must be rendered in a form suitable for the Simatic S7-1500 Controller, using the mathematical operations available to that Controller, these are listed in Table 2.1.
To perform the calculations in the Controller it will be necessary to use partial calculation to hold separate components of the overall calculation and combine these to produce the final result.
The following sections breakdown each of the response calculations into these partial calculations and demonstrate how these are then combined to provide a final result that is compatible with the Controller mathematical operations and Controller notations.
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 3.5.1 Over damped, slow response no overshoot ζ > 1
CALCULATION:
╓ 1 ┌ ζ ┐ - ω [ ζ ─ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t 1 ┌ ζ ┐ - ω [ ζ ┼ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t ╖ y = x K║1 ─ -- │------------------ ┼ 1│ｅ ┼ -- │------------------ ─ 1│ｅ ║ ╙ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘ ╜
Is rendered into the correct format as follows:
cal_01 = SQRT ( SQR (ζ) - 1) = √(ζ² ─ 1)
ζ cal_02 = ζ ÷ cal_01 = ----------------- √(ζ² ─ 1)
cal_03 = ζ + cal_01 = ζ ┼ √(ζ² ─ 1)
cal_04 = -1 × ω × t × cal_03 = - ω [ ζ ┼ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t
-ω [ ζ ┼ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t cal_05 = EXP( cal_04 ) =ｅ
cal_06 = ζ - cal_01 = ζ ─ √(ζ² ─ 1)
cal_07 = -1 × ω × t × cal_06 = - ω [ ζ ─ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t
-ω [ ζ ─ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t cal_08 = EXP( cal_07 ) =ｅ
1 ┌ ζ ┐ cal_09 = (cal_02 - 1) × 0.5 = -- │------------------ ─ 1│ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘
1 ┌ ζ ┐ cal_10 = (cal_02 + 1) × 0.5 = -- │------------------ ┼ 1│ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘
1 ┌ ζ ┐ -ω [ ζ ┼ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t cal_11 = cal_09 × cal_05 = -- │------------------ ─ 1│ｅ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘
1 ┌ ζ ┐ -ω [ ζ ─ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t cal_12 = cal_10 × cal_08 = -- │------------------ ┼ 1│ｅ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘
╓ 1 ┌ ζ ┐ - ω [ ζ ─ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t 1 ┌ ζ ┐ - ω [ ζ ┼ √(ζ² ─ 1) ]t ╖ cal_13 = 1 - cal_12 + cal_11 = ║1 ─ -- │------------------ ┼ 1│ｅ ┼ -- │------------------ ─ 1│ｅ ║ ╙ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘ 2 └ √(ζ² ─ 1) ┘ ╜

▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 3.5.2 Critically damped, fastest response without overshoot ζ = 1
CALCULATION:
╓ - ωt ╖ y = x K║1 ─ (1 ┼ ωt) ｅ ║ ╙ ╜
Is rendered into the correct format as follows:

▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 3.6 Operating modes
This block FC19512_StdDebugInst2Order supports manual and automatic operating modes, the default mode is automatic.
The module can be switched between automatic and manual modes with the mode_AutMan signal:
DATA STRUCTURE UT39512_Dy_DebugInst2Order ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SIGNAL FUNCTION TYPE DETAILS ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― Mode_AutMan Specifies the operating mode of Bool 1 = automatic mode the simulation 0 = manual mode
Mode_ManTime Specifies the manual time value of Real Elapsed time the simulation in seconds in seconds
status_Aut The simulation is in automatic mode Bool 1 = auto mode 0 = not in auto
status_Man The simulation is in manual mode Bool 1 = manual mode 0 = not in manual ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 3.6.1 Automatic mode
By default the module will be in automatic mode.
In automatic mode, if the simulation is active (TRIGGER = 1), the module carries out the relevant calculation (listed in § 3.2) depending on the value of the damping factor (k_DampFactor) each time the module is called. The module calculates the elapsed time based on the current CPU time when the module was called, compared with the CPU time when the simulation was started (rising edge of TRIGGER) and stored in actual_StartTime.
In automatic mode, a real time simulation occurs, generating responses similar to those shown in the plots of § 2.3.
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 3.6.2 Manual mode
In manual mode, if the simulation is active (TRIGGER = 1), the module carries out the relevant calculation (listed in § 3.2) depending on the value of the damping factor (k_DampFactor) each time the module is called; in exactly the same way as automatic mode.
The difference with manual mode, is that the time used in the calculation must be uniquely specified, the elapsed time is not calculated and a manual time value must be provided.
The manual time is given in the variable mode_ManTime and is specified in seconds.
If mode mode_ManTime remains constant between module calls, the module will return the same OUTPUT value each time (assuming all other signals remain unchanged).
Manual mode allows the module to calculate the correct response for a particular and exact time, and is not dependent on cycle times or other factors that may affect when the module is called.
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 3.7 Symbols, block icons and faceplates
There is no supervisory system interface for this block. It is a debug simulation module and as such has no graphical symbol, block icon or faceplate.

Where: ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SCR Source Code Review A visual inspection of the software to ensure it has been written ┌┐ to the correct standards, uses the correct structures within the └┘ software and is generally suitable for deployment.
SMT Software Module Test A full and detailed test of an individual software module in ▛▜ isolation; such testing requires that all branches of the ▙▟ software are tested.
It tests all the interfaces to the module, any data recorded or stored by the module, all error and exception handling functions and tests all timed and interrupt driven operations.
SCV Software Compatibility A mechanism for verifying that no executable code software ╓╖ Verification changes have been made to a module following changes to ╙╜ comment fields.
Allows typographical errors &c. to be corrected without forcing a full SMT on a module that has not functionally changed. ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
An SCV can only be performed on a module that has at some point previously, successfully completed both an SCR and SMT. Where an SCV is implemented, it replaces the requirement for both the SCR and the SMT for the test iteration in question.

Current revision and modification history
▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ Identifies automatic and manual modes and sets the status bits accordingly. ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
SIMULATION — Set Auto/Manual mode

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ If the simulation is not running (TRIGGER = 0), set status to stopped and reset all calculated data and status signals.
If the simulation is not running, the block will terminate at this point. ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
SIMULATION INACTIVE — Reset data — Block end
▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ Reset all ancillary calculation data (this will be updated by calculation type). ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
SIMULATION RUNNING — Reset ancillary data

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ At this point the simulation is running (TRIGGER = 1), read the CPU real time clock and store in the working variable act_CPUTime.
This time is then used as the current time for all calculations within the module. ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
SIMULATION RUNNING — Read current time

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ If the TRIGGER parameter has gone high, and is seen for the first time (status_Running = 0), THEN a rising edge has been detected on the TRIGGER signal (the simulation has started).
If a rising edge is detected: 1. Store the current time (act_CPUTime) as the simulation start time (actual_StartTime) 2. Set the status_Running bit to match the TRIGGER signal 3. Set the status_Stopped bit to match the inverse of the TRIGGER signal ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
SIMULATION RUNNING — Check for TRIGGER rising edge

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ If the TRIGGER parameter is high (the simulation is running), then: Subtract the start time from the current to give the current elapsed time (wrkElapsedTime) ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
SIMULATION RUNNING — Calculate current elapsed time

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ The wrkElapsedTime signal is of data type LTime (a 64-bit number representing the recorded duration in nanoseconds).
This signal is converted first to a LInt (long integer) and then to a REAL number.
This REAL number is then divided by 1,000,000,000 (1×10^9) to convert the duration from nanoseconds to seconds
This final value is returned as actual_RunTime ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
SIMULATION RUNNING — Convert elapsed time to a REAL number in seconds

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ If manual mode is active, the elapsed time is replaced with the manual time (mode_ManTime)
If the manual mode time is negative, the elapsed time is set to zero. ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
SIMULATION RUNNING — Check for manual mode

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ The damping factor determines the type of response: 1. ζ > 1 Stable over damped (no oscillations) status_OverDamp 2. ζ = 1 Stable critically damped (no oscillations) status_CritDamp 3. 0 < ζ < 1 Stable under damped (decaying oscillations) status_UnderDamp 4. ζ = 0 Stable undamped (constant oscillations) status_Undamped 5. -1 < ζ < 0 Unstable under damped (inc. oscillations) status_USUnder 6. ζ ≤ -1 Unstable over damped (asymptotic increase) status_USOver
The indicated status bit will be set high for the associated damping factor value
For responses 1, 2, 3 and 4, status_Stable will be set high, indicating the response is stable. It will be reset for responses 5 and 6.
For responses 3, 4 and 6, status_Osc will be set high, indicating the response is oscillatory. It will be reset for responses 1, 2 and 5. ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
SIMULATION RUNNING — Determine type of response

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ If the damping factor is set to exactly -1.0, the output response can produce and error.
To compensate under these conditions, the damping factor is adjusted to -1.000001, ensuring an accurate response is produced. ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄

The magnitude of the output will be constrained to the limit 9.0 × 10^37, this is within the maximum range of a real number (±3.4 × 10^±38) and is achieved by setting the output to a value of 9.0 × 10^37 if either cal_04 or cal_04 are outside the range -87.0 < cal_04/7 < 87.0.
